Starting point: My sense of history is that it is rare for a large business to announce the complete scrapping of a profitable business segment. So my starting point is an assumption of a low base rate (0-20%) The timeline argument: My overarching assumption here is that companies typically focus on planing for the short term (which is particularly the case for publicly traded ones) and are unlikely to publicly tie themselves to a long-term plan as specific as this, which means that a company would announce this most likely only if it is planning to do so in the short to medium term (i.e. in the next 1-3 years). But then, it seems unlikely that a company can physically accomplish a turn around within a short timeframe. Secondly, the economics might not justify the business case. It seems a stretch to assume that the economics of EVs will pencil out in the short term. For example, GM cross-subsidizes its Bolt from sales of other more profitable cars (https://cleantechnica.com/2017/05/20/ubs-chevy-bolt-drivetrain-4600-cheaper-thought-tesla-model-3-likely-profitable/). Still, battery costs are falling and EV supply chains and manufacturing practices are rapidly improving so it is a possibility that it might make business sense. Yet are there major car companies on this list that have been investing in EVs and batteries enough to be able to pull this off? From my limited knowledge it seems the answer is no. The marketing stunt argument: it might make sense for a company to do this purely for marketing purposes. Many of the brands that qualify for the purposes of this question seem to be small. It is conceivable that the owner of a small subsidiary will use it for this purpose. This is why I am keeping it as a distinct possibility. Of course companies have reasons other than marketing to enter a new and very possibly unprofitable business segment (first mover advantage comes to mind). But they would probably not have to completely give up the sale of other cars to pursue these reasons.
